newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombian stocks dip despite foreign buying.
newsitem.headline: Colombian stocks dip despite foreign buying.

text.p: Colombian stocks drifted down in busy trade despite some foreign fund interest in blue chips, brokers said Tuesday.
Bogota's IBB index dipped 0.45 percent to 834.47 in a 4 billion peso volume. Medellin's IBOMED general price index, meanwhile, ended 0.04 percent down at 13,201.49 in volume of one billion pesos.

"Foreign funds were active today. They were especially active in buying up large packets of attractive shares such as Banco Ganadero, Cementos Argos and insurance company Suramericana de Seguros," a Bogota broker said.
Despite the purchases, neither the market nor the individual stocks were able to overcome the market's ongoing inertia and illqudity.
On the Bogota exchange, Banco Ganadero ordinary shares fell 1.19 percent to 249 in a 1.3 billion peso volume, while Suramericana remained unchanged at 18,500 in a 1.14 billion peso volume.
One broker said he thought most of the 5.5 million shares in Banco Gandero, the country's largest bank in terms of assets, were bought by a single foreign fund.
"The large volumes suggest the buyer was a foreign fund attracted by the share's low price and recent demand on Wall Street. Hopes are also high for good year-end results," the broker added.
However, Ganadero ended lower as the final trade of the day was made at a lower price than earlier transactions.

There was also keen interest in brewing giant Bavaria, unchanged at 4,035 in a 290 million peso volume, and in savings and loans society Sociedad de Ahorro y Capitalizacion Bolivar, also flat at 3,300 in a 396 million peso volume.
Cementos Argos remained unchanged at 5,190 in a 359 million trade.
"It seems foreign funds bought up cement and Bavaria shares in order to meet portfolio requirements," the broker explained.

The Medellin exchange saw another cross-deal in cement manufacturer Cementos Paz del Rio, which remained steady at 880. Bavaria dipped 0.37 percent to 4,035, while cigarette manufacturer Coltabaco was unchanged at 3,000.
